newsitem.title: UK: Investors wary over Trans-World/Russia furore.
newsitem.headline: Investors wary over Trans-World/Russia furore.

text.p: A war of words between Russian officials and big metals exporter Trans-World Group has upset potential investors to Russia's vast but impoverished metals sector.

"People are going to be more reluctant to think about investment in Russia after this," Horst Peters, the Managing Director of Germany's VAW Aluminium-Technologie GmbH, said in the corridors of a London conference on commercial opportunities in Russia's metals sector.
"The pay-back period for capital investment is about 15 years, so its very sensitive to these types of rumours," he added.
Delegates to the conference discussed the pros of investing in Russia's metals industry as well as its cons -- fluctuating taxes, a non-payments crisis and a booming shadow economy.
But on everyone's mind was the furore raised last month when Russian Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov called for more control over foreign participation in the aluminium industry.
Trans-World, which owns a substantial stake in Russian aluminium production, responded this week with an open letter slamming Russia's "craven, political power play."
A Trans-World official at the conference told journalists the company had put on hold further investments into Russia over the incident.
"We want to see an official position by the government before we continue our investment programme in Russia," Mel Wilde, director at Trans-World (Steel) Ltd, told journalists.

In an address to the conference, Wilde also referred to other problems problems of investing in Russia, including unpredictable taxes, very high power costs, and a move by some Russian banks to seek a majority ownership in metal enterprises.
Trans-World announced earlier this week plans to spend $500 million in two large Russian aluminium smelters notwithstanding the stand-off.
Apart from Russian policies, Wilde also criticised what he called a U.S.-led anti-dumping campaign aimed at excluding commodities from the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) from world markets.
"We think this is protectionist policy which if successful will halt overnight CIS exports," he said.
Other delegates said the furore was disturbing but typical from a Russia-savvy investor's point of view.

"It doesn't bother us personally because without the outside financing no one's going to make any money out of our project," said Simon Purkiss, Managing Director of Osmium Holdings S.A. of Luxembourg, which has a joint venture with Russia's massive Norilsk Nickel complex.
"Besides, implenting the measures Kulikov proposed would take about two years. There's obviously concern about this, but it's just part of doing business in Russia," Purkiss said.
